isis.stitle: ALTERNATOR: LEECE NEVILLE AND PRESTOLITE JN SERIES - TROUBLESHOOTING

step1.para: Check the drive belts, wiring, and mounting hardware, and make sure that they are in proper working order.
Check the batteries according to manufacturer specifications to insure that they are in good condition. The batteries must be at least 95-100% charged. If necessary, charge or replace batteries.

To establish if the alternator is functioning properly, connect an accurate test voltmeter to the alternator output terminals (use a voltmeter capable of measuring 1/100 of a volt). With all electrical accessories off, run the engine at approximately 1000-1200 RPM. Voltage reading should be within 13.8 to 14.2 volts.
If the alternator is overcharging, continue with step 7. If a low output condition is noted, then continue with step 4.
Remove regulator from holder far enough to expose the two contact pads. If corrosion or dirt is found, then clean contact pads with #600 (or finer) grade sandpaper.

note.para: Poor contacts between contact pads and brushes may cause a "low charge" condition.

step1.para: Remove brushes and visually inspect them. If brushes appear burned, cracked, broken or if they are worn to a length of 3/16 inch or less, then brushes must be replaced. Check shunt lead within the brush spring. If the shunt lead is broken, then install new brushes. Clean brush contact caps with #600 (or finer) grade sandpaper.
Clean each brush contact cap and the two contact pads on the regulator.
Reinstall the brushes and regulator as shown under REASSEMBLE steps 12 and 13.
Repeat the test in step 3. If the output voltage is below 13.8 volts, the unit should be full field tested as shown in step 6.

Shut off the engine and all electrical accessories. Measure the voltage at the battery terminals and make a note of the reading. Connect a short jumper to the alternator NEGATIVE output terminal and to a 1.5 to 2 inch piece of stiff wire (a piece of paper clip wire is suitable). Insert the wire in the full field access hole as far as it will go ( Figure 28).

Run engine at about 1000-1200 RPM with voltmeter connected to battery terminals and check the voltage. If the voltage rises rapidly above the reading noted when the engine was off, the alternator is OK. Continue with step 7.
If the voltage rises slowly or remains the same, the alternator is defective. Continue with step 8.

step2.para: Pry clamp (toward slip ring end of alternator) to free regulator. Disconnect the three leads and replace regulator with a new one (refer to REASSEMBLE for proper procedure).
Connect battery ground cable, and repeat "Output Test."

note.para: If overcharge condition is still present after regulator replacement, then alternator must be removed and disassembled. The problem may be caused by poor connections of the red and black leads (sensing leads) to the rectifier assembly.

step1.para: To establish which component is causing the alternator to malfunction, perform an AC voltage test.

svcsubproc.title: AC VOLTAGE TEST ( Figure 29)
svcsubproc.para: Run engine at about 1200 RPM, and connect an AC voltmeter across alternator AC terminals 1 & 2, 1 & 3, 2 & 3 and compare each of the three AC voltage readings. If all three AC voltage readings are approximately the same (balanced), the stator is OK. While performing this test, alternator must be in the "full field" mode.
The voltage regulator used in these alternators is a solid state device and for this reason will normally have an extremely long life. It can, however, be damaged by mechanical or electrical abuse.

If the system polarity is inadvertently reversed by installing a battery backwards, boosting or jump starting with the jumper connected backwards, or reversing the positive and negative alternator output leads when changing an alternator, the voltage regulator will be damaged. Although the polarity reversal may only be momentary and may not damage the alternator diodes, the regulator will still be damaged.
